            <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
            <p>An element </p>

         <p class="description">A plan of action and milestones which identifies initial and residual risks, deviations,

            <summary>Remarks</summary>
            <div class="remarks">
               <p>Either an OSCAL-based SSP must be imported, or a unique system-id must be specified.
                  Both may be present.</p>
            </div>

               <h3 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/metadata/published" class="toc3 head">published</h3>
            </div>
            <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/metadata/published">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/metadata/published</a> in the element map.</p>
            <div class="obj-desc">
               <div class="obj-matrix">
                  <p class="obj-name">element Publication Timestamp</p>
                  <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                  <p>An element of type <a href="link.to.dateTime-with-timezone">dateTime-with-timezone</a></p>
               </div>
               <p class="description">The date and time the document was published. The date-time value must be formatted
                  according to <a>RFC 3339</a> with full time and time zone included.</p>
               <div class="value" id="">
                  <p>Value: A dateTime-with-timezone </p>
               </div>
               
               --&gt;      
               <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                  <summary>Remarks</summary>
                  <div class="remarks">
                     <p>This value represents the point in time when the OSCAL document was published. Typically,
                        this date value will be machine generated at the time the containing document is published.</p>
                     <p>In some cases, an OSCAL document may be derived from some source material in a different
                        format. In such a case, the <code>published</code> value should indicate when the OSCAL document was published, not the source material.
                        Where necessary, the publication date of the original source material can be captured
                        as a named property or custom metadata construct.</p>
                     <p>A publisher of OSCAL content can use this data point along with its siblings <code>last-modified</code> and <code>version</code> to establish a sequence of successive revisions of a given OSCAL-based publication.
                        The metadata for previous revisions can be represented as a <code>revision</code> in this object.</p>
                  </div>
               </details>
            </div>
         </section>

               <p class="description">A string used to distinguish the current version of the document from other previous

               </div>
               
               --&gt;      
               <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                  <summary>Remarks</summary>
                  <div class="remarks">
                     <p>A version string may be a release number, sequence number, date, or other identifier
                        suffcient to distinguish between different document versions. This version is typically
                        set by the document owner or by the tool used to maintain the content.</p>
                     <p>While not required, it is recommended that OSCAL content authors use <a>Semantic Versioning</a> as a format for version strings. This allows for the easy identification of a version
                        tree consisting of major, minor, and patch numbers.</p>
                     <p>A publisher of OSCAL content can use this data point along with its siblings <code>published</code> and <code>last-modified</code> to establish a sequence of successive revisions of a given OSCAL-based publication.

               </details>

                              OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                              or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                              and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                              an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                              lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                              consistency.</p>
                           <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                              was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                              of the containing object.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>

                              <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                                 "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                              <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced

               </div>
               <p class="description">A document identifier qualified by an identifier <code>scheme</code>. A document identifier provides a globally unique identifier for a group of documents
                  that are to be treated as different versions of the same document. If this element
                  does not appear, or if the value of this element is empty, the value of "document-id"
                  is equal to the value of the "uuid" flag of the top-level root element.</p>
               <div class="value" id="">

               </div>

               <details open="open" class="remarks-group">

                  <div class="remarks">
                     <p>This element is optional, but it will always have a valid value, as if it is missing
                        the value of "document-id" is assumed to be equal to the UUID of the root. This requirement
                        allows for document creators to retroactively link an update to the original version,
                        by providing a document-id on the new document that is equal to the uuid of the original
                        document.</p>
                  </div>
               </details>

                        <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>

               <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                  <summary>Remarks</summary>
                  <div class="remarks">
                     <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to
                        a back matter <code>resource</code> is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the <code>rlink/hash</code> object.</p>
                     <p>The OSCAL <code>link</code> is a roughly based on the HTML <a>link element</a>. </p>
                  </div>
               </details>

               </div>

                     <p class="obj-name">attribute Hypertext Reference</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>

                  </div>

                  --&gt;      
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                           that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                        <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                           "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                        <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                           resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document
                           containing the link.</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>
            </section>

                     document scoped and is intended to be consistent for the same role across minor revisions
                     of the document.</p>
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>OSCAL has defined a set of standardized roles for consistent use in OSCAL documents.
                           This allows tools consuming OSCAL content to infer specific semantics when these roles
                           are used. These roles are documented in the specific contexts of their use (e.g.,
                           responsible-party, responsible-role). When using such a role, it is necessary to define
                           these roles in this list, which will then allow such a role to be referenced.</p>
                     </div>

                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 to ∞]</span></p>
                     <p>An element </p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                     qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                     may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                           OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                           or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                           and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                           an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                           lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                           consistency.</p>
                        <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                           was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                           of the containing object.</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>

               </section>

                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">attribute Property Namespace</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a></p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                        associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                              names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                              with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                           <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                              to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                           <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>
               </section>

            <section class="xml-element">

                  </div>
                  <p class="description">A reference to a local or remote resource</p>
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to
                           a back matter <code>resource</code> is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the <code>rlink/hash</code> object.</p>
                        <p>The OSCAL <code>link</code> is a roughly based on the HTML <a>link element</a>. </p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>
               <section class="xml-element">
                  <div class="header">

                  </div>

                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
                        <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.uri-reference">uri-reference</a></p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A resolvable URL reference to a resource.</p>
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                              that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                           <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                              "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                           <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                              resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document
                              containing the link.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>
               </section>

                  <h4 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/metadata/location/prop" class="toc4 head">prop</h4>
               </div>
               <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/metadata/location/prop">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/metadata/location/prop</a> in the element map.</p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">element Property</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 to ∞]</span></p>
                     <p>An element </p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                     qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                     may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                           OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                           or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                           and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                           an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                           lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                           consistency.</p>
                        <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                           was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                           of the containing object.</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>

                  <div class="header">

                  </div>

                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">attribute Property Name</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
                        <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.NCName">NCName</a></p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A textual label that uniquely identifies a specific attribute, characteristic, or
                        quality of the property's containing object.</p>

                     --&gt;      </div>

                  </div>

                        <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.uuid">uuid</a></p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A unique identifier that can be used to reference this property elsewhere in an OSCAL
                        document. A UUID should be consistently used for a given location across revisions
                        of the document.</p>
                     
                     --&gt;

               </section>
               <section class="xml-element">
                  <div class="header">

                     <h5 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/metadata/location/prop/@ns" class="toc5 head">@ns</h5>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/metadata/location/prop/@ns">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/metadata/location/prop/@ns</a> in the element map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">attribute Property Namespace</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a></p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                        associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                              names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                              with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                           <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                              to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                           <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>
               </section>

            <section class="xml-element">
               <div class="header">
                  <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/metadata/locations/links"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>
                  <h4 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/metadata/location/link" class="toc4 head">link</h4>
               </div>
               <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/metadata/location/link">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/metadata/location/link</a> in the element map.</p>

                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 to ∞]</span></p>
                     <p>An element </p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">A reference to a local or remote resource</p>
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to
                           a back matter <code>resource</code> is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the <code>rlink/hash</code> object.</p>
                        <p>The OSCAL <code>link</code> is a roughly based on the HTML <a>link element</a>. </p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>
               <section class="xml-element">
                  <div class="header">

                  </div>

                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">attribute Hypertext Reference</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
                        <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.uri-reference">uri-reference</a></p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A resolvable URL reference to a resource.</p>
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                              that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                           <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                              "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                           <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                              resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document
                              containing the link.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>
               </section>

                  <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/metadata/parties/props"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>
                  <h4 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/metadata/party/prop" class="toc4 head">prop</h4>
               </div>
               <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/metadata/party/prop">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/metadata/party/prop</a> in the element map.</p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">element Property</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 to ∞]</span></p>
                     <p>An element </p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                     qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                     may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                           OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                           or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                           and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                           an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                           lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                           consistency.</p>
                        <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                           was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                           of the containing object.</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>
               <section class="xml-element">
                  <div class="header">

                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">attribute Property Name</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
                        <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.NCName">NCName</a></p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A textual label that uniquely identifies a specific attribute, characteristic, or
                        quality of the property's containing object.</p>
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     
                     --&gt;      </div>
               </section>

                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">attribute Property Universally Unique Identifier</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.uuid">uuid</a></p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A unique identifier that can be used to reference this property elsewhere in an OSCAL
                        document. A UUID should be consistently used for a given location across revisions
                        of the document.</p>
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     
                     --&gt;      </div>
               </section>
               <section class="xml-element">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/metadata/parties/props/ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>
                     <h5 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/metadata/party/prop/@ns" class="toc5 head">@ns</h5>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/metadata/party/prop/@ns">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/metadata/party/prop/@ns</a> in the element map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">attribute Property Namespace</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a></p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                        associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                              names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                              with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                           <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                              to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                           <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>
               </section>
               <section class="xml-element">

            <section class="xml-element">
               <div class="header">
                  <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/metadata/parties/links"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>

                  <p class="description">A reference to a local or remote resource</p>
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to
                           a back matter <code>resource</code> is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the <code>rlink/hash</code> object.</p>
                        <p>The OSCAL <code>link</code> is a roughly based on the HTML <a>link element</a>. </p>
                     </div>
                  </details>

               <section class="xml-element">

                  </div>

                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">attribute Hypertext Reference</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
                        <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.uri-reference">uri-reference</a></p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A resolvable URL reference to a resource.</p>
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                              that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                           <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                              "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                           <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                              resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document
                              containing the link.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>
               </section>

               <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/metadata/responsible-party/prop">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/metadata/responsible-party/prop</a> in the element map.</p>

                  <div class="obj-matrix">

                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 to ∞]</span></p>
                     <p>An element </p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                     qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                     may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                           OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                           or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                           and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                           an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                           lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                           consistency.</p>
                        <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                           was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                           of the containing object.</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>

                  <div class="header">
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/metadata/responsible-parties/props/ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>
                     <h5 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/metadata/responsible-party/prop/@ns" class="toc5 head">@ns</h5>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/metadata/responsible-party/prop/@ns">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/metadata/responsible-party/prop/@ns</a> in the element map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">attribute Property Namespace</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a></p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                        associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                              names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                              with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                           <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                              to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                           <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>
               </section>

            <section class="xml-element">
               <div class="header">
                  <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/metadata/responsible-parties/links"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>
                  <h4 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/metadata/responsible-party/link" class="toc4 head">link</h4>
               </div>
               <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/metadata/responsible-party/link">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/metadata/responsible-party/link</a> in the element map.</p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">

                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 to ∞]</span></p>
                     <p>An element </p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">A reference to a local or remote resource</p>
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to
                           a back matter <code>resource</code> is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the <code>rlink/hash</code> object.</p>
                        <p>The OSCAL <code>link</code> is a roughly based on the HTML <a>link element</a>. </p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>
               <section class="xml-element">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/metadata/responsible-parties/links/href"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>

                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/metadata/responsible-party/link/@href">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/metadata/responsible-party/link/@href</a> in the element map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">attribute Hypertext Reference</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
                        <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.uri-reference">uri-reference</a></p>
                     </div>

                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                              that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                           <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                              "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                           <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                              resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document
                              containing the link.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>
               </section>

            </div>
            <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/import-ssp/@href">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/import-ssp/@href</a> in the element map.</p>
            <div class="obj-desc">
               <div class="obj-matrix">
                  <p class="obj-name">attribute System Security Plan Reference</p>
                  <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
                  <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.uri-reference">uri-reference</a></p>
               </div>
               <p class="description">&gt;A resolvable URL reference to the system security plan for the system being assessed.</p>
               <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                  <summary>Remarks</summary>
                  <div class="remarks">
                     <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                        that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                     <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                        "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is <a>within the scope of the containing OSCAL document</a>.</p>
                     <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                        resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document
                        containing the link.</p>
                  </div>
               </details>
            </div>
         </section>

         <section class="xml-element">
            <div class="header">
               <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/components"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>

            </div>
            <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/component">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/component</a> in the element map.</p>
            <div class="obj-desc">
               <div class="obj-matrix">
                  <p class="obj-name">element Component</p>
                  <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 to ∞]</span></p>
                  <p>An element </p>
               </div>
               <p class="description">A defined component that can be part of an implemented system.</p>
               
               --&gt;      
               
               --&gt;      
               <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                  <summary>Remarks</summary>
                  <div class="remarks in-use">
                     <p class="nb">(In use)</p>
                     <p>Used to add any components, not defined via the System Security Plan (AR-&gt;AP-&gt;SSP)</p>
                  </div>
                  <div class="remarks">
                     <p>Components may be products, services, application programming interface (APIs), policies,
                        processes, plans, guidance, standards, or other tangible items that enable security
                        and/or privacy.</p>
                     <p>The <code>type</code> indicates which of these component types is represented.</p>
                     <p>When defining a <code>service</code> component where are relationship to other components is known, one or more <code>link</code> entries with rel values of provided-by and used-by can be used to link to the specific
                        component identifier(s) that provide and use the service respectively.</p>
                  </div>
               </details>
            </div>
            <section class="xml-element">

               </div>
               <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/component/purpose">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/component/purpose</a> in the element map.</p>
               <div class="obj-desc">

            <section class="xml-element">
               <div class="header">
                  <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/components/props"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>
                  <h4 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/component/prop" class="toc4 head">prop</h4>
               </div>
               <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/component/prop">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/component/prop</a> in the element map.</p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">element Property</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 to ∞]</span></p>
                     <p>An element </p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                     qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                     may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                           OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                           or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                           and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                           an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                           lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                           consistency.</p>
                        <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                           was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                           of the containing object.</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>
               <section class="xml-element">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/components/props/name"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>
                     <h5 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/component/prop/@name" class="toc5 head">@name</h5>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/component/prop/@name">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/component/prop/@name</a> in the element map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">attribute Property Name</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
                        <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.NCName">NCName</a></p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A textual label that uniquely identifies a specific attribute, characteristic, or
                        quality of the property's containing object.</p>
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     
                     --&gt;      </div>
               </section>
               <section class="xml-element">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/components/props/uuid"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>
                     <h5 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/component/prop/@uuid" class="toc5 head">@uuid</h5>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/component/prop/@uuid">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/component/prop/@uuid</a> in the element map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">attribute Property Universally Unique Identifier</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.uuid">uuid</a></p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A unique identifier that can be used to reference this property elsewhere in an OSCAL
                        document. A UUID should be consistently used for a given location across revisions
                        of the document.</p>
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     
                     --&gt;      </div>
               </section>
               <section class="xml-element">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/components/props/ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>
                     <h5 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/component/prop/@ns" class="toc5 head">@ns</h5>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/component/prop/@ns">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/local-definitions/component/prop/@ns</a> in the element map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">attribute Property Namespace</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                        <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a></p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                        associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                              names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                              with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                           <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                              to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                           <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>
               </section>
               <section class="xml-element">

                        <div class="remarks">

                              OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                              or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                              and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                              an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                              lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                              consistency.</p>

                              <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                                 names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated

                        <div class="remarks">

                              a back matter <code>resource</code> is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the <code>rlink/hash</code> object.</p>

                                 that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                              <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                                 "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                              <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced

                                 containing the link.</p>

                              <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                                 "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                              <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced

                              <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                                 names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                                 with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                              <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                                 to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                              <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                           </div>
                        </details>
                     </div>
                  </section>

                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to
                              a back matter <code>resource</code> is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the <code>rlink/hash</code> object.</p>
                           <p>The OSCAL <code>link</code> is a roughly based on the HTML <a>link element</a>. </p>
                        </div>
                     </details>

                  <section class="xml-element">

                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                                 that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                              <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                                 "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                              <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                                 resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document
                                 containing the link.</p>
                           </div>
                        </details>

                        </div>
                        <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                           qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                           may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                        
                        --&gt;

                        --&gt;

                        <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                           <summary>Remarks</summary>
                           <div class="remarks">
                              <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                                 OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                                 or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                                 and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                                 an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                                 lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                                 consistency.</p>
                              <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                                 was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                                 of the containing object.</p>
                           </div>
                        </details>
                     </div>

                                    that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                                 <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                                    "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                                 <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced

                                    containing the link.</p>

               <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                  qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which

               <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                  <summary>Remarks</summary>
                  <div class="remarks">
                     <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                        OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                        or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                        and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                        an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                        lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                        consistency.</p>
                     <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                        was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                        of the containing object.</p>
                  </div>
               </details>

                     <p class="obj-name">attribute Property Universally Unique Identifier</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                     <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.uuid">uuid</a></p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">A unique identifier that can be used to reference this property elsewhere in an OSCAL
                     document. A UUID should be consistently used for a given location across revisions
                     of the document.</p>
                  
                  --&gt;      </div>
            </section>
            <section class="xml-element">
               <div class="header">
                  <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/props/ns"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>
                  <h4 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observation/prop/@ns" class="toc4 head">@ns</h4>
               </div>
               <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observation/prop/@ns">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observation/prop/@ns</a> in the element map.</p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">attribute Property Namespace</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                     <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.uri">uri</a></p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">A namespace qualifying the property's name. This allows different organizations to
                     associate distinct semantics with the same name.</p>
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>Provides a means to segment the value space for the <code>name</code>, so that different organizations and individuals can assert control over the allowed
                           names and associated values used in a property. This allows the semantics associated
                           with a given name/value pair to be defined on an organization-by-organization basis.</p>
                        <p>An organization MUST use a URI that they have control over. e.g., a domain registered
                           to the organization in a URI, a registered uniform resource names (URN) namespace.</p>
                        <p>When a <code>ns</code> is not provided, its value should be assumed to be <code>http://csrc.nist.gov/ns/oscal</code> and the name should be a name defined by the associated OSCAL model.</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>
            </section>
            <section class="xml-element">
               <div class="header">
                  <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/props/value"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>
                  <h4 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observation/prop/@value" class="toc4 head">@value</h4>
               </div>
               <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observation/prop/@value">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observation/prop/@value</a> in the element map.</p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">attribute Property Value</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
                     <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.string">string</a></p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">Indicates the value of the attribute, characteristic, or quality.</p>
                  
                  --&gt;      </div>
            </section>

                     <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.NCName">NCName</a></p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">A textual label that provides a sub-type or characterization of the property's <code>name</code>. This can be used to further distinguish or discriminate between the semantics of
                     multiple properties of the same object with the same <code>name</code> and <code>ns</code>. </p>
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>A <code>class</code> can be used in validation rules to express extra constraints over named items of
                           a specific <code>class</code> value.</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>
            </section>

                     <p>Value: A markup-multiline </p>
                  </div>
                  
                  --&gt;      </div>

         <section class="xml-element">
            <div class="header">
               <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/links"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>
               <h3 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observation/link" class="toc3 head">link</h3>
            </div>
            <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observation/link">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observation/link</a> in the element map.</p>
            <div class="obj-desc">
               <div class="obj-matrix">
                  <p class="obj-name">element Link</p>
                  <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 to ∞]</span></p>
                  <p>An element </p>
               </div>
               <p class="description">A reference to a local or remote resource</p>
               
               --&gt;      
               
               --&gt;      
               <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                  <summary>Remarks</summary>
                  <div class="remarks">
                     <p>To provide a cryptographic hash for a remote target resource, a local reference to
                        a back matter <code>resource</code> is needed. The resource allows one or more hash values to be provided using the <code>rlink/hash</code> object.</p>
                     <p>The OSCAL <code>link</code> is a roughly based on the HTML <a>link element</a>. </p>
                  </div>
               </details>
            </div>
            <section class="xml-element">
               <div class="header">
                  <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/links/href"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>
                  <h4 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observation/link/@href" class="toc4 head">@href</h4>
               </div>
               <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observation/link/@href">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observation/link/@href</a> in the element map.</p>
               <div class="obj-desc">
                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">attribute Hypertext Reference</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
                     <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.uri-reference">uri-reference</a></p>
                  </div>
                  <p class="description">A resolvable URL reference to a resource.</p>
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                     <summary>Remarks</summary>
                     <div class="remarks">
                        <p>The value of the <code>href</code> can be an internet resource, or a local reference using a fragment e.g. #fragment
                           that points to a <code>back-matter</code> <code>resource</code> in the same document.</p>
                        <p>If a local reference using a fragment is used, this will be indicated by a fragment
                           "#" followed by an identifier which references an identified <code>resource</code> in the document's <code>back-matter</code> or another object that is within the scope of the containing OSCAL document.</p>
                        <p>If an internet resource is used, the <code>href</code> value will be an absolute or relative URI pointing to the location of the referenced
                           resource. A relative URI will be resolved relative to the location of the document
                           containing the link.</p>
                     </div>
                  </details>
               </div>
            </section>
            <section class="xml-element">
               <div class="header">
                  <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/links/rel"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>

               </div>

                  <div class="obj-matrix">
                     <p class="obj-name">attribute Relation</p>
                     <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                     <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.NCName">NCName</a></p>
                  </div>

                  --&gt;      
                  
                  --&gt;      
                  
                  --&gt;      </div>
            </section>

                  --&gt;

            </section>

         <section class="xml-element">
            <div class="header">

               <h3 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observation/origin" class="toc3 head">origin</h3>
            </div>
            <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observation/origin">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observation/origin</a> in the element map.</p>
            <div class="obj-desc">
               <div class="obj-matrix">

               </div>
               <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observation/origin/actor">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observation/origin/actor</a> in the element map.</p>

                  <div class="obj-matrix">

                     --&gt;      
                     
                     --&gt;      </div>
               </section>

                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observation/origin/actor/@role-id">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observation/origin/actor/@role-id</a> in the element map.</p>

                     --&gt;      </div>
               </section>
               <section class="xml-element">
                  <div class="header">
                     <div class="crosslink"><a href="../json-reference/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observations/origins/actors/props"><button class="schema-link">Switch to JSON</button></a></div>
                     <h5 id="/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observation/origin/actor/prop" class="toc5 head">prop</h5>
                  </div>
                  <p>See <a href="../xml-outline/#/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observation/origin/actor/prop">/plan-of-action-and-milestones/observation/origin/actor/prop</a> in the element map.</p>
                  <div class="obj-desc">
                     <div class="obj-matrix">
                        <p class="obj-name">element Property</p>
                        <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 to ∞]</span></p>
                        <p>An element </p>
                     </div>
                     <p class="description">An attribute, characteristic, or quality of the containing object expressed as a namespace
                        qualified name/value pair. The value of a property is a simple scalar value, which
                        may be expressed as a list of values.</p>
                     
                     --&gt;      
                     <details open="open" class="remarks-group">
                        <summary>Remarks</summary>
                        <div class="remarks">
                           <p>Properties permit the deployment and management of arbitrary controlled values, within
                              OSCAL objects. A property can be included for any purpose useful to an application
                              or implementation. Typically, properties will be used to sort, filter, select, order,
                              and arrange OSCAL content objects, to relate OSCAL objects to one another, or to associate
                              an OSCAL object to class hierarchies, taxonomies, or external authorities. Thus, the
                              lexical composition of properties may be constrained by external processes to ensure
                              consistency.</p>
                           <p>Property allows for associated remarks that describe why the specific property value
                              was applied to the containing object, or the significance of the value in the context
                              of the containing object.</p>
                        </div>
                     </details>
                  </div>
                  <section class="xml-element">
                     <div class="header">

                     </div>

                     <div class="obj-desc">
                        <div class="obj-matrix">
                           <p class="obj-name">attribute Property Name</p>
                           <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[1]</span></p>
                           <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.NCName">NCName</a></p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">A textual label that uniquely identifies a specific attribute, characteristic, or
                           quality of the property's containing object.</p>
                        
                        --&gt;      
                        
                        --&gt;      </div>
                  </section>

                     </div>

                     <div class="obj-desc">
                        <div class="obj-matrix">
                           <p class="obj-name">attribute Property Universally Unique Identifier</p>
                           <p class="occurrence"><span class="cardinality">[0 or 1]</span></p>
                           <p>An attribute of type <a href="link.to.uuid">uuid</a></p>
                        </div>
                        <p class="description">A unique identifier that can be used to reference this property elsewhere in an OSCAL
                           document. A UUID should be consistently used for a given location across revisions

                        --&gt;      </div>
                  </section>
